text: Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: I would say I wouldn’t want to look back and not do everything I could have done. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: We might not cure you, but I think psychologically, you know I’ve done everything I can. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: But that you know, people feel differently. The only thing I say is you know to people is you really, really do have to do the radiation and the hormones. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: And that’s, and the data is clear. Everything else we’re doing you have to do is you know unmeasurable. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Because if you do the radiation and hormones you have a fifty/fifty shot at being cured. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So if the cancer never comes back you don’t know if what we did helped or not. Right, I admit that.

text: Family Member 1: I see. Doctor: So it’s, But it’s irrelevant. The cancer’s out. It’s an aggressive cancer. Family Member 1: Um Hmm. Patient: What are the side effects from the chemo and super hormones? Doctor: Yeah, uh so the biggest side effect, quite frankly, so let’s talk about hormones first. Uh because the super hormones don’t add anything. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, but hormone therapy, uh as far as I’m concerned, it’s the worst part of the whole thing, right. It’s gonna put you into menopause, it stills your sex drive, it gives you hot flashes, and it slows your metabolism by you know twenty-five percent, so you have to decrease your calorie intake. And you have to exercise like a fiend, or you’re going to get fat, and you don’t want that. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um but the other thing is it just makes you more tired, you know. We’re making you into an eight-year-old guy – Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: -temporarily. Family Member: For two years.

text: Family Member: Six. Doctor: So it was forty-six, forty-three, forty-nine. So that’s almost the same number to me, maybe a little bit elevated from the last time. So the only thing that’s changed is you have a couple of lymph nodes in the abdomen, pelvis that are, got a little bit bigger. Patient: Oh they have gotten? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So what, so what does that tell us? Doctor: Well, it’s confusing because some are actually smaller. Uh up in the chest. So one for instance was point nine centimeters. Now it’s point six. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
